awd_titl_txt: NSFGEO-NERC Quantifying disequilibrium processes in basaltic volcanism (DisEqm)
awd_abstract_narration:
Although most basaltic eruptions erupt lava, they can also be explosive.  An understanding of what controls the eruptive style will lead to better assessment of hazards, such as those to aviation (explosive ash) and to the environment around the volcano (effusive). Most previous work on the controls of explosive versus effusive eruption assumed that crystals and gas are in equilibrium with the melt as it travels from deep within the Earth. This assumption is faulty, however, because crystals and bubbles grow so fast that they are commonly out of equilibrium. A novel x-ray imaging technique will be used to measure the compositions and growth rates of crystals and bubbles under realistic eruption conditions. The project involves an international team of investigators, each of whom will tackle a different part of this integrative project. The United States investigators will integrate the experimental results into computational models to assess how the magma fragments as it is erupting and how ash is transported in the atmosphere.

NSF funding is being provided to U.S. investigators who are part of an international team that will assess the importance of disequilibrium processes during basaltic eruptions. X-ray tomography will be performed on decompressing and cooling natural magmas using a diamond light source synchrotron. These measurements will quantify the growth rates, distribution, and compositions of crystal, gas, and melt phases under conditions that are close to those of a natural eruption. The role of the U.S. investigator is to incorporate these parameters into a computational code that simulates magma transport through an eruptive conduit. The truly novel aspect is that previous models assume equilibrium between the phases, but the measurements made as part of this project will provide the necessary parameters to model disequilibrium bubble and crystal growth. The conduit model will then be coupled to a model of an atmospheric eruptive column. These models predict textures and modal contents of the eruptive products, as well as the deposits' distributions, permitting field tests of the numerical models.

por.por_cntn:
Volcanic eruptions of very fluid magma called basalt dominates volcanism on Earth, Mars, the Moon, and Venus. Because of the fluid nature of basalt magmas, they typically produce non-explosive lava flows or mild explosive eruptions.  However, it is becoming more commonly recognized that such volcanoes can also produce more destructive explosive eruptions that deposit volcanic ash and scoria (pulverized magma) over broad areas potentially causing widespread property damage (Figure 1). One of the most violent eruptions of this type occurred at Sunset Crater, about 15 miles NE of Flagstaff, AZ.  The eruption clearly impacted inhabitants over a large area, causing them to move away from the volcano and dramatically alter their settlement style and food production. A similar modern eruption scenario could significantly affect the Western US, potentially causing major disruption to air traffic at multiple major hubs and adversely impacting regional agriculture and infrastructure such as highways and power grids.  One of the many goals of this project was to assemble and rigorously test tools for forecasting the possible impact of one such eruption.

Mount Etna (Sicily) typically effuses lava flows amid small explosive bursts, but Etna has also experienced many medium to large explosive eruptions in the last 2000 years.  Some recent eruptions of Etna have been well-documented in real-time and their impacts have been quantified, thus making them well-suited to testing (benchmarking) a forecasting model.  As one part of this project, we successfully modeled the well-documented November 24, 2006 eruption of Mt. Etna using a plume dynamics model (PlumeMoM) coupled with an atmospheric dispersal model (HySPLIT) (Figure 2). PlumeMoM (Developed by our Italian colleagues; freely available at GitHub) focuses on the jet or plume generated by an explosive eruption and simulates how high volcanic ash is injected into the atmosphere.  HySPLIT, a product of the National Atmospheric and Oceanic Administration, simulates how that ash, once injected into the atmosphere, is then transported by the wind field and ultimately deposited over the landscape.  During a series of tests, we continuously compared simulations to the real event, and these comparisons drove additional model development, which ultimately improved comparisons between model and the real world (Figure 3).  Because of our efforts, the coupled models are now considered to be a reliable way to forecast future impact of similar volcanic eruptions.

We are now in the process of conducting a more applied follow-up to the project by simulating a possible large-scale eruption of Etna in order to forecast its impact.  This forward-looking study is being conducted in collaboration with scientists of the Italian National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology.  Similarly, we are working with the US Geological Survey to forecast a possible future event in the Western US, originating from various possible sources in Washington, Oregon, Nevada, California, Utah, Arizona, and New Mexico.
